metadata.case_name: Anirara Basumatari v. Khagendranath and Hkim Chandra Rabha

facts.text: An election was held in the double-member constituency of Goalpara to the Assam Legislative Assembly.
Nomination papers were filed on 19th January 1957 by a number of persons including Anirara Basumatari, candidate for the seat reserved for scheduled tribes.
Nomination paper of Anirara Basumatari rejected by returning officer on ground disqualified under s.7(b) of Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Anirara Basumatari convicted under s.4(b) of Explosive Substances Act, 1908, sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment on 10 July 1953.
Sentence remitted by Government of Assam on 8 November 1954 under s.401 CrPC, released on 14 November 1954.
Polling took place on 25 February 1957; Khagendranath and Hkim Chandra Rabha elected, latter member of scheduled tribe.

Election petition filed by an elector challenging election of two successful candidates on grounds: wrongful rejection of Basumatari's nomination and corrupt practice of carrying voters on mechanically propelled vehicles.
Election tribunal held nomination paper improperly rejected, corrupt practice not proved, set aside election.

Appeal by successful candidates to Assam High Court in First Appeal No.11 of 1958; High Court held nomination properly rejected, no corrupt practice, allowed appeal, dismissed election petition on 12 August 1958.
Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.
Appellant applied to Election Commission to remove disqualification, refused.
Voters carried on mechanically propelled vehicles to polling booths by Birendra Kumar Nath (in-charge of Congress campaign) and Bholaram Sarkar (president Primary Congress Committee).

legal_issues.text: Whether the nomination paper of the appellant was properly rejected under s.7(b) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, in view of the remission of his sentence.

Whether a corrupt practice under s.100(1)(b) read with s.123(5) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, was committed by carrying voters in mechanically propelled vehicles with consent of successful candidates.

petitioner_arguments.text: Remission of sentence under s.401 CrPC reduced effective sentence to less than two years, so no disqualification under s.7(b) RPA.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7(b) Representation of the People Act, 1951; s.401 CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Voters carried by agents of successful candidates (Congress nominees) in mechanically propelled vehicles, with their consent.

respondent_arguments.text: State Government had no authority to remit sentence in view of Constitution Articles 72,73,161,162 read with s.401 CrPC.
Even if remission valid, it does not reduce sentence imposed by court; disqualification remains under s.7(b).
No proof of consent, express or implied, of successful candidates to corrupt practice.

court_reasoning.text: Remission under s.401 CrPC does not wipe out conviction or reduce sentence imposed by court; it only affects execution of sentence. Disqualification under s.7(b) based on court-imposed sentence of more than two years, not actual undergone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of remission affects execution but leaves conviction and sentence untouched.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent finding of tribunal and High Court that no consent of candidates to corrupt practice; inference of fact not interference in appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proof of consent, express or implied.

holdings.text: Nomination paper properly rejected as appellant disqualified under s.7(b) RPA; remission does not reduce court sentence.
No corrupt practice proved due to lack of consent of candidates.

precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of remission wipes out remitted portion but does not change court sentence; dealt with cancellation of remission.
Incorrectly held remission equivalent to court reduction; likely pardon in that case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Meenakshi Mills, Madurai v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Inference of fact from circumstances not question of law.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for election; corrupt practice of conveyance by vehicles.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment that nomination paper was properly rejected under s.7(b) RPA due to disqualification from conviction and sentence not reduced by remission, and no corrupt practice proved; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "An order of remission thus does not in any way interfere with the order of the court; it affects only the execution of the sentence passed by the court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing remission from sentence reduction.

key_quotes.text: "s.7(b) speaks of the conviction and sentence passed by a court of law; it does not speak of the period of imprisonment actually suffered."
key_quotes.speaker: court
